drugDetails.content:
Preamble

PEP is Post-Exposure Prophylaxis.

It means taking antiretroviral medicines (ART) after being potentially exposed to HIV to prevent becoming infected.

Indications and Usage

PEP should be considered if you’ve had a recent possible exposure to HIV at work.

Report your exposure to your supervisor, and seek medical attention immediately.

Occupational transmission of HIV to health care workers is extremely rare, and the proper use of safety devices and barriers can help minimize the risk of exposure while caring for patients with HIV.

Dosage and Administration

PEP must be started within 72 hours after a recent possible exposure to HIV, but the sooner you start the PEP, the better.

Every hour counts.

If you're prescribed PEP, you'll need to take it once or twice daily for 28 days.

PEP is effective in preventing HIV when administered correctly, but not 100%.

PEP normally consists of three anti-HIV drugs, from two of the different classes.

(A regimen for post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred).

TDF + 3TC (or FTC) + EFV as a fixed-dose combination is recommended as the preferred option to initiate ART for adults and adolescents.

Remember to take an HIV test 3 months after exposure.

Pregnant and breastfeeding women can be treated with PEP.

Contraindications

Do not treat pregnant women with Efavirenz or Nevirapin.

Adverse Reactions

HIV treatment can cause side-effects which tend to be the worst when you first start taking them.

If you are taking PEP you may experience some unpleasant side-effects such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, headaches and fatigue.

The drugs used in a course of PEP today are less likely to cause side-effects than those used in the past.

chapters.content:
Using alcohol-based handrub is indicated when hands are visibly clean.

Use alcohol-based handrub before and after every procedure, such as before and after touching a patient, after touching patient's surroundings, before a clean procedure, after body fluid exposure risk and before and after wearing gloves.

Guide to Local Production:

WHO-recommended handrub formulations.

Liquids Required

  • Ethanol 96% OR Isopropyl alcohol 99.8%
  • Hydrogen peroxide 3%
  • Glycerol 98%
  • Sterile distilled OR boiled cold water

Materials Required

  • 10-litre glass or plastic bottles with screw-threaded stoppers, OR
  • 50-litre plastic tanks (preferably in polypropylene or high density polyethylene, translucent so as to see the liquid level), OR
  • Stainless steel tanks with a capacity of 80-100 litres (for mixing without overflowing)
  • Wooden, plastic or metal paddles for mixing
  • Measuring cylinders and measuring jugs
  • Plastic or metal funnel
  • 100 ml plastic bottles with leak-proof tops, OR
  • 500 ml glass or plastic bottles with screwtops.
    An alcoholmeter: the temperature scale is at the bottom and the ethanol concentration (percentage v/v) at the top.

Note:

    Glycerol: used as humectant, but other emollients may be used for skin care, provided that they are cheap, widely available and miscible in the water and alcohol and do not add to toxicity, or promote allergy.
    Hydrogen peroxide: used to inactivate contaminating bacterial spores in the solution and is not an active substance for hand antisepsis.
    Any further additive should be clearly labelled and be non-toxic in case of accidental ingestion.
    A colourant may be added to allow differentiation from other fluids, but should not add to toxicity, promote allergy, or interfere with antimicrobial properties. The addition of perfumes or dyes is not recommended due to risk of allergic reactions

10-litre preparations:

These can be prepared in 10-litre glass or plastic bottles with screw-treaded stoppers.

Recommended amounts of products:

10-litre preparations

Formulation 1

  • Ethanol 96%: 8333 ml
  • Hydrogen peroxide 3%: 417 ml
  • Glycerol 98%: 145 ml
  • Sterile distilled or boiled cold water: 1105 ml

Formulation 2

  • Isopropyl alcohol 99.8%: 7515 ml
  • Hydrogen peroxide 3%: 417 ml
  • Glycerol 98%: 145 ml
  • Sterile distilled or boiled cold water: 1923 ml

Final products:

Formulation 1

Final concentrations:

  • Ethanol 80% (v/v)
  • Glucerol 1.45% (v/v)
  • Hydrogen peroxide 0.125% (v/v)

Formulation 2

Final concentrations:

  • Isopropyl alcohol 75% (v/v)
  • Glycerol 1.45% (v/v)
  • Hydrogen peroxide 0.125% (v/v)

Step by Step Preparation:

1. The alcohol (Ethanol or Isopropyl) for the formula to be used is poured into the large bottle or tank up to the graduated mark.

2. Hydrogen peroxide is added using the measuring cylinder

3. Glycerol is added using a measuring cylinder.

As glycerol is very viscous and sticks to the wall of the measuring cylinder, it should be rinsed with some sterile distilled or cold boiled water and then emptied into the bottle/tank.

4. The bottle/tank is then topped up to the 10-litre mark with sterile distilled or cold boiled water

5. The lid or the screw cap is placed on the tank/bottle as soon as possible after preparation, in order to prevent evaporation.

6. The solution is mixed by shaking gently where appropriate or by using a paddle.

7. Immediately divide up the solution into its final containers (e.g. 500 or 100 ml plastic bottles), and place the bottles in quarantine for 72 hours before use.

This allows time for any spores present in the alcohol or the new/re-used bottles to be destroyed.

1. Pre-production analysis should be made every time an analysis certificate is not available to guarantee the titration of alcohol (i.e. local production).

Verify the alcohol concentration with the alcoholmeter and make the necessary adjustments in volume in the preparation formulation to obtain the final recommended concentration.

2. Post-production analysis is mandatory if either ethanol or an isopropanol solution is used.

Use the alcoholmeter to control the alcohol concentration of the final use solution.

The accepted limits should be fixed to ± 5% of the target concentration (75%–85% for ethanol).

3. The alcoholmeter shown in the image above is for use with ethanol; if used to control an isopropanol solution, a 75% solution will show 77% (± 1%) on the scale at 25°C.

Labelling should be in accordance with national guidelines and should include the following:

  • Name of institution, date of production and batch number.
  • WHO-recommended hand rub formulation.
  • For external use only.
  • Avoid contact with eyes.
  • Keep out of reach of children.
  • Date of production and batch number.
  • Use: Apply a palmful of alcohol-based handrub and cover all surfaces of the hands. Rub hands for 20- 30 seconds.
  • Composition: Ethanol or isopropanol, glycerol and hydrogen peroxide.
  • Flammable: Keep away from flame and heat.

• Production and storage facilities should ideally be air conditioned or cool rooms. No naked flames or smoking should be permitted in these areas.
  • WHO-recommended handrub formulations should not be produced in quantities exceeding 50- litres locally or in central pharmacies lacking specialised air conditioning and ventilation.
  • Since undiluted ethanol is highly flammable and may ignite at temperatures as low as 10°C, production facilities should directly dilute it to the above mentioned concentration.
  • The flashpoints of ethanol 80% (v/v) and of isopropyl alcohol 75% (v/v) are 17.5°C and 19°C, respectively.
  • National safety guidelines and local legal requirements must be adhered to the storage of ingredients and the final product.

Using 0.5% Chlorine Solution is indicated when instruments can be decontaminated and when to mix a disinfection solution used for cleaning high-risk areas.

Disinfection solution is made with detergent and 0.5% Chlorine Solution.

Chlorine in liquid bleach comes in different concentrations.

Any concentration can be used to make a dilute chlorine solution by applying the following formula:

% Chlorine in liquid bleach
Chlorine desired (0.5%)
-1
=
Total parts of water for each part of bleach

Example: To make a 0.5% chlorine solution from 5% bleach:

5%
0.5%
-1
=
9 parts of water for each part of bleach

Therefore, you must add 1 part of 5% bleach to 9 parts water to make a 0.5% chlorine solution.

Parts can be used for any unit of measure (e.g. litre or gallon) or any container used for measuring, such as a pitcher.

In countries where French products are available, the amount of active chlorine is usually expressed in degrees chlorum.

One degree chlorum is equivalent to 0.3% active chlorine.

questions.question: Who do you protect by following the infection prevention recommendations?
questions.description: By following the infection prevention recommendations you protect the patient and yourself.

questions.question: Infections cannot be prevented, True or False?
questions.description: False, infections can be prevented.

questions.question: What is hand hygiene?
questions.description:
Hand hygiene is defined as:

Using alcohol-based handrub.

Washing hands with soap and running water.

answers.value: Washing hands with soap and running water

questions.question: When should you use alcohol-based handrub?
questions.description:
You should use alcohol-based handrub:

Before and after each procedure.

When hands are visibly clean.

questions.question: Which soap is best to use?
questions.description: The best soap to use is liquid soap from a dispenser

answers.value: Plain soap in a wet container
Plain soap placed in a rack that drains

questions.question: What personal protective equipment at a minimum should you wear while attending a birth?
questions.description: You should, as a minimum wear a clean apron, gloves and closed footwear while attending a birth.

questions.question: If you are running out of gloves, you can use the same pair of gloves for different patients. True or False?
questions.description: False, you should never use the same pair of gloves for different patients.

questions.question: What do you use for cleaning your instruments?
questions.description: You use a soap solution made of water and detergent to clean your instruments.

answers.value: A solution made of water, chlorine and bar soap
A solution made of water, chlorine and detergent
A solution made of water and detergent

questions.question: When are sterile items at risk of becoming contaminated?
questions.description: Sterile items are at risk of becoming contaminated when placed in a sterilized container that is repeatedly opened and closed.

answers.value: When placed in a small, dry sterile container
When placed in a sterilized container that is repeatedly opened and closed

questions.question: Where should sterile items be placed?
questions.description: Sterile items should be placed in a closed cabinet

answers.value: On a shelf so they are easily accessible
Unpacked, at the operational table, ready for use

questions.question: It is not necessary to clean the delivery bed if there was no birth on the bed. True or False?
questions.description: False, it is necessary to clean the delivery bed even if there was no birth on the bed.

questions.question: Which vaccination should all healthcare workers have?
questions.description: All healthcare workers should have a Hepatitis B vaccination.

questions.question: Identify some of the major complications associated with maternal death
questions.description:
Some of the major complications associated with maternal death are:

Hypertensive disorder.

Infections.

Severe bleeding.

questions.question: Identify some of the major complications associated with  neonatal death (0-28 days after birth)
questions.description:
Some of the major complications associated with  neonatal death (0-27 days after birth) are:

Neonatal sepsis.

Prematurity.

questions.question: What is the main cause of infections?
questions.description: The main cause of infections is invisible germs.

questions.question: When healthcare workers transfer germs to patients, how does it primarily occur?
questions.description: Healthcare workers primarily transfer germs to patients through the healthcare workers’ contaminated hands.

questions.question: How is the correct way to perform hand hygiene if your hands are visible clean?
questions.description: Alcohol-based handrub kills most germs.

answers.value: Washing hands with soap and running water

questions.question: Can germs hide under rings, wristwatches and bracelets?
questions.description: Yes, germs can hide under rings, wristwatches and bracelets as it is difficult to clean your jewellery and wristwatch free of germs.

answers.value: No, when hands are washed all germs are gone.
Yes, it is difficult to clean your jewellery and wristwatch free of germs.

questions.question: What should you do if you don’t have paper towels to dry hands with?
questions.description: If you don’t have paper towels to dry hands with, use a clean towel that has not been used before.

answers.value: Use a clean towel that has not been used before

questions.question: Shared towels cannot transfer germs to hands. True or False?
questions.description: False, shared towels can indeed transfer germs to hands.

questions.question: When should you perform hand hygiene?
questions.description:
You should perform hand hygiene:

After contact with patient’s surroundings.

Before a clean procedure.

Before wearing gloves and after removing gloves.

answers.value: Before wearing gloves and after removing gloves

questions.question: In what order should cleaning and storage be arranged?
questions.description:
Cleaning and storage shold be arranged in following order: 

1. Contaminated items 
2. Cleaning
3. Sterilization / High-level disinfection
4. Storage

questions.question: Why is it important to organize the cleaning process?
questions.description: By separating the dirty and clean area contamination are avoided.

answers.value: To avoid contamination by separating the dirty and clean areas
To prevent the healthcare workers from cleaning the instruments

keyLearningPointDetails.description: Spread of HIV and Hep. B

questions.question: How can HIV and Hepatitis B spread?
questions.description: HIV and Hepatitis B only spread through infectious fluids such as blood, genital and amniotic fluids and blood stained fluids.

answers.value: Through all types of body fluids
Through infectious fluids (blood, genital and amniotic fluids and blood stained fluids)

questions.question: When should you choose handrub instead of handwash?
questions.description:
You should choose handrub instead of handwash:

When leaving the clinic.

Before and after each procedure.

questions.question: When should you wash your hands?
questions.description:
You should wash hands:

When hands are visibly dirty.

After touching body fluids.

questions.question: What is the procedure for handwashing?
questions.description:
The procedure for handwashing is:

1. Turn on the water from the tap 
2. Position the hands and wrist downward as you wet them and apply soap
3. Perform 6 steps of rubbing movements
4. Rinse hands with clean running water

answers.value: Turn on the water from the tap
Position the hands and wrist downward as you wet them and apply soap
Rinse hands with clean running water

questions.question: For each procedure, how much alcohol-based handrub do you need?
questions.description: For each procedure, you need one palmful of alcohol-based handrub to clean your hands.

questions.question: If you run out of alcohol-based handrub what do you do?
questions.description:
If you run out of alcohol-based handrub what do you:

Make it yourself.

Ask somebody at the clinic to make it.

Wash your hands instead.

answers.value: Ask somebody at the clinic to make it
I do not perform hand hygiene

questions.question: Labelling on the alcohol-based handrub bottle is important. True or False?
questions.description: True, labelling on the alcohol-based handrub bottle is important.

questions.question: What should you be aware of when removing gloves?
questions.description: When removing gloves you should be aware of not allowing the outside surface to come in contact with the skin.

answers.value: To put them in chlorine solution for reuse
To wash them with soap and water
Not to allow the outside surface to come in contact with the skin

questions.question: Which gloves are recommended while attending a birth?
questions.description: Sterile gloves are preferred while attending a birth.

questions.question: When should you use a disinfection solution?
questions.description: You should use disinfection solution in high-risk areas which consists of table, delivery bed, walls, ceiling, floor and toilet.

answers.value: In a high- and low-risk area

questions.question: When is the transmission of HIV and Hepatitis B most likely?
questions.description: Transmission of HIV and Hepatitis B is most likely by inoculation through the skin.

questions.question: What should you do if you are exposed to HIV or hepatitis B?
questions.description: If you are exposed to HIV or hepatitis B you should take post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP).

questions.question: Should soap be placed in a wet container?
questions.description: No, soap should not be placed in a wet container, because germs will grow.

answers.value: Yes, because when the soap is already wet, you save water

questions.question: Why is it not recommended to air-dry hands after hand wash?
questions.description: It is recommended to use paper towel after hand wash if available

questions.question: How do you mix alcohol-based handrub?
questions.description: You mix alcohol-based handrub by following the Safe Delivery App formula.

answers.value: Follow the Safe Delivery App formula
